NEWS'

Food service at Hopkins has never been subject to
favorable criticism. There are few undergraduates who
enjoyed eating in the dorms as freshmen and few
upperclassmen who enjoy eating in Levering now. The
installation of microwave ovens and plasticburgers in
Levering last year made food service there intolerable.
While the changes made in that operation this year
have improved the situation, the proposals made by
the Food Committee point toward sweeping revisions
in the present system which would vastly improve the
food available on campus.
The proposal to set up a food service in the Student
Union operating on a break-even basis will certainly
result in better quality food. If a single contractor is
operating the service, as is suggested by the
Committee, on a break-even basis, money normally
held as profit will be spent for more edible .food. There
is little question that a good food service is essential to
the Student Union facility, so people can go there and
get a decent meal. The Committee has also
recommended that students take over the Snack Bar
operation in the dorms. Such a system would provide
students with the opportunity to run the food service
they use and be responsible for it.
However, while these suggestions hold promise for
the future, the University must not neglect the present
need for upgrading existing food, service. No one
should have to wait for the new Student Union to be
built before they can get a good meal on campus.

By JACKIE ECKHART
Some books should never become
movies, for in the transition they become
mutilated, or. at the very least, sadly
misinterpreted. I don't know if anyone
could make a movie capturing the ideals
of A Separate Peace by John Knowles,
but I do know that director Larry Peerce
did not do so. There are a few successful
elements in this movie, but many others
which make watching it close to
unbearable.
It seems as if Peerce decided to take
advantage of the Lore Story. Summer of
'42 audience, but his production has
neither the tear-jerking melodrama nor
nostalgic humor. His actors fail to pry
any emotion from the viewer except
embarrassment for their awkwardness.
(John Heyl and Parker Stevenson are
given their debuts in the starring roles.)
Peerce had a chance to make an
important movie, and he missed it
through poor directing and an
unfortunate attempt at relevancy. The

story in the novel and the movie is the
same, but only the original is successful.
The film fails miserably.
Gene and Phineas are two seventeen
year olds attending the Devon School for
boys during the Second World War. The
core of A Separate Peace is Phineas' fall
from a tree for which Gene was probably
responsible. The natural rivalry between
the two boys is the motivation for this
"accident" which puts an end both to
Phineas' athletic prowess and Gene's
jealousy. Although Phineas' life is
profoundly altered at the hands of Gene.
the two remain inextricably tied, to one
another. The primary theme of the novel
is this unusual friendhip and the
development of the two boys through it.
The fact that there is a war going on is
only secondary to this major idea: the
bond between two teenage boys.
Peerce's skill as a director is simply
absent, as is any development of the
primary theme. A potentially poignant
scene in which the relationship between

Gene and Phineas could have been
explored is ruined both by their acting
(Phineas: "Did I —pause— ever tell you
—pause— that I used to be aiming for the
—pause— Olympics?") and by the
appearance of a huge and unexplainably
empty gymnasium. This most likely is an
allusion to a World War ll hangar, only
one of the numerous war references
which clutter the movie.
Perhaps it was in his desire for relev
ancy that Peerce played up the war
theme. He even goes so far as to make an
obvious and contemptible reference to
Nixon a recruiter says. "I want to make
on thing perfectly clear." In any case, this
attempt at relevancy fails and only serves
to make the real theme of the movie
illusive, so much so, in fact, that it cannot
be found.
The camera work of this film doesn't
begin to compensate for the clumsiness of
the actors or their mismanagement of the
lines. In fact, it just adds to the multitude
of annoying elements for which the
director is responsible. It should strike
any viewer that distorted scenes and
cliche effects are being offered to him —
and he should reject them.
And, if sloppy acting, nonexistent
themes, and shaky cameras don't get to
you. Phineas' whistle will. This irritating
air makes wall-climbing a tempting
possibility. None of these atrocities are
present in 'Knowles' novel, and we have
Larry Peerce to thank for their presence
in the film.
It can, perhaps, be argues that a movie
should not be judged on its similarity (or
lack of it) to the parent novel. But "A
Separate Peace" remains a horrible movie.
Out of them all, perhaps the worst
feature of the film is its attempt at
relevancy, for I think we've all tired of
that.

By JACKIE ECKHART
Some books should never become
movies, for in the transition they become
mutilated, or. at the very least, sadly
misinterpreted. I don't know if anyone
could make a movie capturing the ideals
of A Separate Peace by John Knowles,
but I do know that director Larry Peerce
did not do so. There are a few successful
elements in this movie, but many others
which make watching it close to
unbearable.
It seems as if Peerce decided to take
advantage of the Lore Story. Summer of
'42 audience, but his production has
neither the tear-jerking melodrama nor
nostalgic humor. His actors fail to pry
any emotion from the viewer except
embarrassment for their awkwardness.
(John Heyl and Parker Stevenson are
given their debuts in the starring roles.)
Peerce had a chance to make an
important movie, and he missed it
through poor directing and an
unfortunate attempt at relevancy. The

story in the novel and the movie is the
same, but only the original is successful.
The film fails miserably.
Gene and Phineas are two seventeen
year olds attending the Devon School for
boys during the Second World War. The
core of A Separate Peace is Phineas' fall
from a tree for which Gene was probably
responsible. The natural rivalry between
the two boys is the motivation for this
"accident" which puts an end both to
Phineas' athletic prowess and Gene's
jealousy. Although Phineas' life is
profoundly altered at the hands of Gene.
the two remain inextricably tied, to one
another. The primary theme of the novel
is this unusual friendhip and the
development of the two boys through it.
The fact that there is a war going on is
only secondary to this major idea: the
bond between two teenage boys.
Peerce's skill as a director is simply
absent, as is any development of the
primary theme. A potentially poignant
scene in which the relationship between

Gene and Phineas could have been
explored is ruined both by their acting
(Phineas: "Did I —pause— ever tell you
—pause— that I used to be aiming for the
—pause— Olympics?") and by the
appearance of a huge and unexplainably
empty gymnasium. This most likely is an
allusion to a World War ll hangar, only
one of the numerous war references
which clutter the movie.
Perhaps it was in his desire for relev
ancy that Peerce played up the war
theme. He even goes so far as to make an
obvious and contemptible reference to
Nixon a recruiter says. "I want to make
on thing perfectly clear." In any case, this
attempt at relevancy fails and only serves
to make the real theme of the movie
illusive, so much so, in fact, that it cannot
be found.
The camera work of this film doesn't
begin to compensate for the clumsiness of
the actors or their mismanagement of the
lines. In fact, it just adds to the multitude
of annoying elements for which the
director is responsible. It should strike
any viewer that distorted scenes and
cliche effects are being offered to him —
and he should reject them.
And, if sloppy acting, nonexistent
themes, and shaky cameras don't get to
you. Phineas' whistle will. This irritating
air makes wall-climbing a tempting
possibility. None of these atrocities are
present in 'Knowles' novel, and we have
Larry Peerce to thank for their presence
in the film.
It can, perhaps, be argues that a movie
should not be judged on its similarity (or
lack of it) to the parent novel. But "A
Separate Peace" remains a horrible movie.
Out of them all, perhaps the worst
feature of the film is its attempt at
relevancy, for I think we've all tired of
that.

Jays trounce Swarthmore 30-8 in best effort
By MIKE LATAPE
In their best game of the
season, the Johns Hopkins varsity
football team trounced
Swarthmore by a score of 30-8
last Saturday. The final score was
not a true indication of the
dominance displayed by the Blue
Jay eleven.
Nor did the statistics tell the
true story. Hopkins led in first
downs (19-14), net yards rushing
(236-91) and total yards
(342-259). A better indication of
the nature of Blue Jay
sukeriority is that Coach Denny
Cox was substituting freely near
the end of the second quarter.
Fine Job
As usual, the defense did a fine
job in thwarting the Swarthmore
attack. After an initial Garnet
first down, the defense stiffened,
forcing Swarthmore to punt.
After taking over at midfield,
Hopkins scored six plays later on
a four yard run by Bill Nolan.
Jack Thomas kicked the extra
point, making the score 7-0.
Highlights of the drive were a
32 yard pass from quarterback
Thomas to Nolan, a slashing
seven yard run by Tim Doyle,
and a seven yard pass from
Thomas to tight end Mike
Bogdan which set up the Nolan
run. On that reception, Bogdan
reinjured his left ankle and did
not see action for the rest of the
game.
After an exchange of punts,
the Garnets found themselves on
the Hopkins 42. Swarthmore
obligingly fumbled the ball with
Mike Seider and Jim Moran
pouncing on the pigskin at the 34

yard line.
But the Hopkins offense was
thwarted and Thomas was forced
to punt. And punt he did —
booming a 63 yard beauty which
was returned by the home team
to their 14.
Later
Three plays later the defense
scored. Jim Moran, Craig Stevens,
and Mike O'Brien cornered the
Swarthmore quarterback in the
end zone for a safety, upping the
score to 9-0.
On the first play of the second
quarter, Thomas was intercepted.
Again the defense rose to the
occasion. On the next play, Craig
Stevens (playing before half the
town of Longmeadow, Mass.)
intercepted the pass and returned
the ball to the Swarthmore 20.
Five plays later, Thomas fired a
strike to wide receiver Grant
Shevchik in the end zone. The
kick by Thomas made the score
16-0.
Interception
Jack Coulter stopped the next
Garnet drive with an
interception. Thomas hit Nolan
with a 17 yard pass, but the drive
stalled there. After Thomas' 35
yard punt, Gunter Glocker
recovered a fumble on the
Swarthmore 37. Two plays later,
Thomas tossed a swing pass to
fullback Jim Ferguson. Ferguson
lugged the ball over the goal line,
good for a 34 yard touchdown.
With the kick, the score climbed
to 23-0.
With 5:35 remaining in the
second quarter, Cox began to
shuffle people in and out of the
game and from offense to

defense and back again. The half
ended with the score 23-0.
Cox inserted his starting unit
in the game to start the second
half. The Blue Jays scored the
first time they had the ball with
Thomas bootlegging 14 yards
around left end. His kick upped
the score 30-0. Instrumental in
the drive, was the running of Tim
Doyle and Nolan who picked up
39 yards M the drive.
Insertions

first units and inserted everybody
but himself and the other
coaches. Stated Cox,"One of the

meaningless as far as the outcome
of the game was concerned, but
it gave the home crowd
something to cheer about.
Good Day
And it was a good day overall.
No fumbles were lost and only
one pass was intercepted. The
offense came through and turned
the contest into a laugher.
Thomas averaged 48.3 yards for
three punts, a respectable figure
in any league. From any angle,
the Swarthmore victory was
definitely a good win for the
Blue Jays.
